content: The "Silver Alert Grant Program Act of 2008" aims to establish a grant program to improve State-administered notification systems for finding missing seniors and individuals with Alzheimer's or dementia-related illnesses. It also seeks to promote best practices for Silver Alert systems and increase awareness for coordinated efforts in locating missing individuals quickly. The Congress finds that Alzheimer's disease affects millions in the US, with a higher risk for older individuals. The aging population will lead to more cases in the future. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60% of patients will wander away from their care facilities. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have implemented notification systems similar to the Amber Alert for missing seniors with dementia. Timely dissemination of information increases the chances of locating missing individuals. Other states have faced challenges in developing such systems due to budget constraints. The Sense of Congress is that Silver Alert systems should have clear criteria for issuing alerts, not based solely on age, and only for individuals unable to make personal decisions. Alerts should be initiated by someone who has recent contact with the missing individual. Alerts should be initiated by someone who has recent contact with the missing individual. Silver Alerts should protect the privacy and dignity of the individuals, encourage training for law enforcement officers on locating missing individuals with dementia-related illnesses, and promote coordination between State and local entities. The Federal Government can play a role in preventing injuries and loss of life among those with dementia. The Federal Government aims to prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses by assisting States in establishing, implementing, and improving Silver Alert systems. The Silver Alert System Grant Program aims to assist States in establishing, implementing, and improving systems to prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The Attorney General can award grants to States to establish or improve Silver Alert systems. Grants are for one-year periods and must be at least $100,000. Regulations will be set within a year to determine eligibility and selection criteria. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,600,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2009 through 2013 to carry out this section. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT ON SILVER ALERT SYSTEMS. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems, including a list of states with the system, number of alerts issued, successful locates, time taken to locate individuals, issuing agency, costs, criteria for alerts, and success rates in finding missing individuals. The Attorney General's annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes information on missing individuals crossing State lines, actions taken to protect privacy and dignity, communication improvements between families and authorities, and any other relevant details determined by the Attorney General. The Silver Alert system is a State-administered notification system to locate missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States and its territories.
